results.title: Energy, food and exercise
results.creator_credit: Roger Lupton, Barry Pierce and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A humorous presentation equating the human body with a machine. Raises issues about the effects of lifestyle on health, bodyweight and fitness. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Dream house
results.creator_credit: John Honey and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Puppets go through the steps of building the Australian “dream house” with disastrous results. The second part of the film examines the many legal pitfalls, and suggestions are made for the wise consumer to follow.

results.title: Freestyle and backstroke
results.brief_description: Part of the Competitive swimming series. Studies the underwater action of a team of Olympic swimmers. Demonstrates arm stroke technique, the twobeat kick and sixbeat flutter kick and breathing techniques. Excellent underwater photography. Variation between male and female swimmers.

results.title: Competitive diving : Basic diving skills
results.brief_description: Covers basic skills of springboard and tower diving - approaches, take-offs, and basic dive positions (tuck, pike, straight and entry). No other credits available.

results.title: Water power
results.creator_credit: Robin Ridgway, Graham Smart and Gateway Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Shows ways in which water wheels operate and generate electricity. Other ways of making use of water power are examined. The film takes an historical approach.
Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: The Big picture: conservation treatment of a large painting
results.creator_credit: Ian Hart, Canberra. College of Advanced Education. Media Centre and Department of Home Affairs
results.brief_description: Conservators, Allan Byrne and Tom Dixon, discuss the restoration of the huge oil paint by Tom Roberts entitled “The Opening of the First Parliament of the Australian Commonwealth by His Majesty King George V (when Duke of York). 9th May 1901”. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels and tertiary/teacher level.

results.title: Famous men and fair women
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Pioneers of photography”.
Julia Margaret Cameron was an outstanding photographer of her day. Despite the restrictions of her social position, she became a recognised artist of portrait photography. Many notable individuals such as Charles Darwin and Alfred Lord Tennyson, were included amongst her subjects. The film gives insight into the social and cultural environment and the moral attitudes that affected concepts of beauty. Demonstrations of photographic procedures used during the 1800’s such as the sliding box camera, plates etc., is also shown. Narrated by Brian Coe.

results.title: Energy: a national issue
results.creator_credit: Gerard H. Baldwin, Ross M Sutherland, Hanna-Barbera Productions and Instructional Media
results.brief_description: Animated film featuring the Flintstones with narration by Charlton Heston to explain the problems of a dwindling energy supply and the means by which to obtain more efficient energy use. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Kelly gang
results.brief_description: Restored by the National Film and Sound Archive, this film represents a substantial proportion of the original footage produced by Harry Southwell in 1920. Starring Godfrey Cass as Ned Kelly, the film includes both outdoor scenes and badly dressed roofless studio interiors that reflect Southwell’s inexperience as a producer.

results.title: Like two mountaineers: the development of Cubism
results.creator_credit: Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: Using examples from the Modern Masters exhibition, this film traces the early influences of Suerat, Cezanne and African art on the development of Cubism. Paintings of Picasso and Braque are shown in great detail from the period when they worked “like two mounaineers roped together”. No commentary, music soundtrack only. Suitable for upper secondary level.
